results.justification: The document explicitly states its methodology as a literature review and subsequent analysis of papers from LAK conferences. "In line with the purpose of this article to contribute to not only understanding how LA research approaches and presents generalisability, but also to inform and enhance the generalisability of future LA research, we took inspiration from [10] methodology and analysed 144 full research papers from the three most recent LAK conferences – LAK ’22, 23 and 24."

The document provides a detailed, step-by-step description of the analysis process, including coding heuristic development, inter-rater reliability checks, and the categorization process. "Following the coding process used by [28] (p. 306) the two authors discussed (1) how each one would approach the deductive and inductive analysis; (2) in what order would we code; (3) how we defined/would approach each of the terms central to the analysis; (4) how we would differentiate between closely related terms such as generalisability and transferability; and (5) how we would approach a coding when we were not sure."
The document provides a link to the working sheets: "We have also made available the working sheets in this link: https://kortlink.dk/2qx3t"

The document describes the coding heuristic used, effectively serving as a codebook. "We have also made available the working sheets in this link: https://kortlink.dk/2qx3t" and the description of the coding heuristic before the analysis.

The document clearly describes the data collection methods, specifying the conferences (LAK '22, '23, '24) and the type of documents analyzed (full research papers). "we analysed 144 full research papers from the three most recent LAK conferences – LAK ’22, 23 and 24."
The document does not mention sharing any code used for the analysis.
Since no code is shared, there are no scripts for data cleaning, analysis, or visualization included.

The document mentions the use of Fleiss’ kappa to assess inter-rater reliability, a statistical measure. "According to [18], a kappa value above 0.81 indicates strong agreement, 0.61–0.80 signifies good agreement, 0.41–0.60 reflects fair consensus, andvaluesbelow0.41suggestpooragreement. Thefinal kappa when comparing the results of the coding authors indicated a good level of agreement (^ = 0.76, subjects=154, raters= 2, andp <0.005) with low measure of controversy."

The document describes the use of thematic analysis and inductive coding, which are qualitative methods. "Once again, the coding and theming process was informed by [28]. Both researchers coded the limitations’ section with specific attention to how authors suggested addressing the limitations’ sections, after which the differences in coding were discussed and resolved and collectively themed."
The document does not mention any preregistration.

The document presents the categorization of papers (Table 1) and the themes extracted from the analysis (Table 2), effectively sharing the outcomes of the experiment. "As can be seen in the above table (Table 1),44% (n= 64) of the papers were found to fall inCategory 4 where limitations were explicitly acknowledged and generalisability AND/OR replicability AND/OR reproducibility AND/OR transferability, but with no reference to scale/scalability."
The document explicitly discusses the limitations of the study. "Our paper on examining the lack of generalisability in LA has cer- tain limitations."
